channel.title: Posts on Jesse Manschot
channel.description: Recent content in Posts on Jesse Manschot

item.title: Ultra Short: Morning Sortie
item.description: It always strikes me how gracefully gliders are lifted into the sky and seeing them fly on the currents above is like looking at an aquarium. I wanted to capture a snippet of that observation in this short animation.

item.title: River bank Impression
item.description: Another impression, this time of a river bank…

item.title: Two Moor Impressions
item.description: I went on a long walk through forests and across moors…

item.title: A New Year's Blessing
item.description: My blessing for the year ahead.

item.title: Calligraphy Gestures
item.description: A couple of poses made with watercolor and a Japanese calligraphy pen.

item.title: Ultra Short: Sapling's Fall
item.description: This started out as a simple experiment of a tree bending in the wind, but I realized I could create a tiny story around it.

item.title: Blizzard children
item.description: Grabbing materials at hand to construct a world.

item.title: Submerged
item.description: Another Day for Night test; this time a bit more elaborate.

item.title: Day for Night
item.description: Testing a Day for Night technique by drawing on paper with opposite colors and inverting it back in post.

item.title: Resting in the Mud
item.description: Another attempt at ‘mixed media’ animation, combining analog charcoal drawings with digitally animated characters.

item.title: The Values of Sky
item.description: Two more charcoal studies of the local sky.

item.title: The Values of Landscape
item.description: Four landscape studies using charcoal to capture value and tone.

item.title: The Zen of Ice Skating
item.description: I went back to (mostly) analogue animating for this one. The character is drawn with a calligraphy pen and the background cycle is made of charcoal drawings. All was composited in Opentoonz and digitally colored in Krita.

item.title: Combining 2D with 3D in Blender
item.description: I was curious to see if it would be possible to create a sense of depth with 2D animation, a medium in which the third dimension seemingly lacks. Something like a virtual diorama where flat elements are positioned deliberately to give an illusion of depth.

item.title: Secondary Action
item.description: An exercise in secondary action and weight. I also wanted to test a digital cel animation workflow with added shadows.

item.title: Speed sketching on a Pen Display
item.description: Recently I acquired a pen display to draw and animate with. I decided to record my timed pose studies to gain an objective view of the way I draw. This is a compilation of the sketches I did of poses ranging between 1-, 2- and 4 minutes.

item.title: 11 Second Club: July entry
item.description: My entry for the 11 Second Club july edition. It is the first time I’m entering this competition and also my first time animating a more rounded (human) character.

item.title: The Animation Workshop: Personal Scene
item.description: During a summer school at The Animation Workshop we had to make our own scene based on a simple prompt: “What was that?” All staging, thumbnailing, animating and background creation was done in TVPaint.

item.title: The Animation Workshop: Animation Exercises
item.description: I visited the animation summer school at The Animation Workshop in Viborg, Denmark this year. We got to learn a lot about the fundamentals and principles of animating and drawing. This was also my first (proper) introduction to using TVPaint and a Wacom tablet to animate digitally.

item.title: The Animation Workshop: Gesture & Croquis
item.description: During the animation summer school at The Animation Workshop I attended gesture and croquis classes. They both ranged between 1 minute, 2 minutes and 4 minutes per pose.

item.title: Three colored poses
item.description: Three scribbly poses made with bold marker and colored pencils.

item.title: Struggling with Feet - part 1
item.description: Trying to tackle the drawing of feet. 3B pencil on paper.

item.title: Lifting a rock (in pastel)
item.description: A return to the basic animation principles: a character lifting something heavy. I wanted an element of slapstick in the scene, hence the hat.

item.title: Calligraphy poses
item.description: An attempt at using a calligraphy brush and watercolour paint to capture the human form. I applied the brush on A3 sized smooth watercolouring paper. The poses were between 2-3 minutes. The colours are inverted for clarity (but also because the amber looks really cool). See below for the originals in blue.

item.title: Stuck in the mud
item.description: Technically a walkcycle, but the character takes quite a few frames to even take one step. I wanted to get to a sense of the forces that occur when a character wants to move forward, but is held back by external circumstances. He could be stuck in mud or something else that’s sticky.

item.title: Frogs and Cycles (of Life)
item.description: This proved to be a study in efficiency: when to cycle and repeat through certain frames in order to extend the animation.

item.title: Cel animation and frogs
item.description: In this exercise I wanted to try the (digital) cel animation technique.

item.title: Pose Studies
item.description: Pose drawings varying between 2 and 5 minutes. Conté and watercolour on paper.

item.title: Throwing a Boomerang
item.description: This time I tried my hand at motion blurring, overlapping action, cutting to a new shot and compositing on backgrounds.

item.title: Watercolour Weekend
item.description: Some watercolour sketches of mental imagery made during the weekend.

item.title: Struggling with Hands - part 2
item.description: More studies of my left hand in various poses. Also tried drawing with a Wacom (last 2).

item.title: Struggling with Hands - part 1
item.description: Trying to tackle the rendering of hands by studying and drawing my own left hand.

item.title: Struggling with Heads - part 3
item.description: Structuring the head in simple planes to get a better sense of how it manifests itself in 3D space. The more complicated the planes the closer it comes to an actual human face, like adding more polygons to a 3D-model.

item.title: Struggling with Heads - part 2
item.description: Diving into the basic bone structure of the head and figuring out how everything fits. Heads are weird.

item.title: Struggling with Heads - part 1
item.description: My first foray into understanding and drawing basic heads. To be continued…

item.title: Even more figure drawing Stickybones
item.description: More figure drawings of a Stickybones mannequin in various poses and angles. Originally blue pencil on white paper, but inverted to examine linework.

item.title: Figure drawing Stickybones
item.description: Figure drawings of a Stickybones mannequin in various poses and angles.

item.title: Weight & Hard Accent
item.description: Trying to give weight (or no weight) to a feather and also an attempt at animating anticipations and ‘hard accents’: the arm anticipates and moves abruptly to catch the feather.

item.title: Walkcycle in Perspective
item.description: An exercise in animating a walkcycle on the third Z-dimension. Though animated on 3’s, it’s interesting to see that the further away the character gets, the less the animation seems to be ‘limited’ or jaggy because of the increased overlap in the spacing between the individual frames. I suppose one could get away with animating characters or objects in the distance on 3’s. I used the technique from Richard Williams' book on where to place the key positions:

item.title: 2 Minute Poses with pen
item.description: Figure drawings of 2 minute poses with pen on paper. The shading is added in a later stage with conté.

item.title: 5 Minute Poses
item.description: Figure drawings of 5 minute poses made with conté on paper. Trying to add more mass and shading this time.

item.title: More pose studies
item.description: Figure drawings of 1 minute poses. Conté on paper. ‘Robo Bean’ studies of twisting torso’s:

item.title: 16 frame walk + overlapping action
item.description: In this animation I tried to combine multiple exercises: 2 subjects reacting to each other A 16-frame “leisurely” walkcycle on 2’s and bringing it to a halt Animating overlapping action; in this case, the opened box lids drag behind its core movement. Also, the head of the figure extends slightly more after its back has arched backwards. Small expression animations, which added up to a total of 4 animation layers.

item.title: Headturn
item.description: My first attempt at a headturn. Animated on 2’s. Initial layout:

item.title: 8 Frame Runcycle on 1's
item.description:
A runcycle where one step spans 8 frames. The arm swing is kept to a minimum to prevent too much action happening in a short amount of time. Here it is on 2’s:
Initial layout:

item.title: Breaking joints
item.description: An exercise in ‘breaking joints’ where the elbows twist and turn in a way only possible in animation. Also added a secondary animation layer; in this case the eyes.

item.title: Timed pose studies
item.description: 1 Minute poses: 30 Second poses: 45 Second poses: Abstracting torso’s with two bean shapes in perspective: Scribbly poses where the pencil stays on the paper, 30 seconds:

item.title: Falling flour sack
item.description: Study of a sack of flour falling to the ground. Traditionally animated on 2’s.

item.title: Various Watercolor sketches
item.description: Various watercolor sketches and studies.
